ygData.msgSnippet: ... networks ... one. In ... stable for ... 100,000 ... Sorry I ve been a bit behind on following this thread so this answer may be obsolete by now, but it is

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> Derek James wrote:

> 
> >3) Are 100,000 time steps necessary?  It seems to us that all 
networks
> >we've looked at so far either fail or succeed very early in each
> >trial, (e.g., <10,000 timesteps).  This would greatly increase
> >efficiency to truncate the amount of timesteps.
> >  
> >
> I think you're right for all experiments except the anti-wiggle 
one. In 
> that experiment I noticed some networks could keep the system 
stable for 
> quite some time only to fail dramatically some time before the 
100,000 
> timesteps where up.
> 
> Colin

Sorry I've been a bit behind on following this thread so this answer 
may be obsolete by now, but it is not so much a question of what is 
necessary as much as just being consistent with past experiments 
(after all, that's what makes it a benchmark).   Certainly there are 
cases once in a while where a 10,000 timestep network can fail at 
100,000 timesteps.  Whether that matters, or whether all our lives 
would have been easier if they'd originally just decided to call it 
a day at 10,000 is no longer really possible to debate unless you 
want to stop comparing with predecessors.  Personally, I would have 
preferred to stop at 10,000.  Then again, Gruau may have had good 
reason for the 100,000 test.

ken
